posts.name: Isaac Mendoza
posts.cooked: Our team has been using 6-gauge power wire for some time, and we are now considering switching to 4-gauge wire due to its lower resistance and the fact that many top bots in our district use 4-gauge or smaller sizes. Could someone please provide a comparison of the advantages and disadvantages of these two options?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
We switched from 6 AWG to 4 AWG batteries this year due to concerns about warmth during swaps. Our battery cables are relatively short—approximately four inches—and one cable connecting to the PDP is just an inch long. Although we haven’t systematically measured the electrical impact, we’ve avoided the “warm wires” issue experienced with 6 AWG. A challenge is adapting 4 AWG cables to the Anderson terminals, though it’s feasible.

Our observations indicate that long runs of 12 AWG significantly affect performance. For instance, an 8-foot run to an algae-shooting motor causes a measurable voltage drop, resulting in a brief loss of power (about one volt) and approximately 60 watts of energy dissipated in the wires.

posts.name: Isaac Mendoza
posts.cooked:
Sure! Here's the cleaned-up version of your text:

"Do you typically use 4-gauge wire in SB-50 or SB-120 applications? Additionally, I’m wondering about the cost implications of switching to 4-gauge wire—how did that change affect your costs?"

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: We use SB50 since we have many. It's unreasonable to try inserting a thicker wire into the 6-gauge terminal. If starting anew, SB120 would be more appropriate. The cost of the wire is negligible, as we rarely use such lengths.

posts.name: Jeremiah Johnson
posts.cooked:
Do you guys put 4 gauge wire into SB 50’s or SB 120’s? Also, I’m concerned about the price of switching to 4 gauge; how did that change go for you?

If you’re considering switching to 4 gauge wire, I recommend using SB 120s instead of SB 50s, as the latter can only handle up to 6 gauge.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
We switched from 6 to 4 AWG cables a few years back and recently acquired the SB120 connectors. This modification helps slightly reduce voltage drop, though it's challenging to measure exactly how much benefit it provides. If you consistently draw over 200A, it might be worth considering. However, it's advisable to approach this upgrade only during times when you're seeking small improvements and be prepared to invest both time and money.

In addition to the increased cost, this adaptation introduces another challenge: unplugging the SB120 connectors can sometimes cause minor discomfort or wear, especially if there are metal edges near them.

Please visit our website here for purchasing adapters that allow you to connect to older robots, lend batteries to other teams, or attach batteries to existing chargers. These adapters will add to the overall cost, but they offer flexibility.

This upgrade comes with added expenses and potential inconvenience, particularly when disassembling the SB120 connectors, which can sometimes cause minor discomfort or wear, especially if there are metal corners nearby.

link_counts.title: SB120 to SB50 Battery Adapter Cable - AndyMark, Inc

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked: With the power-hungry devices currently in use (Kraken, Vortex), minimizing the resistance along the current pathway from the battery to the end-device is essential for improving efficiency. Evaluate all options, including CTRE's Power Distribution Panel and REV's Power Distribution Hub, and base your decisions on the data provided.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked:
To clean up the given text effectively, follow these steps: 1. **Remove HTML Tags**: Eliminate all `<` and `
Programming4907:

Remember you have to purchase some adapters too. These are for plugging into old robots, lending batteries to other teams, and plugging your batteries into existing battery chargers.

You can also just make adapters yourself, which is cheaper than buying them from Andymark, especially if you have SB50s just sitting around. Use very short 6ga wires between the SB50 and SB120 connectors (about 2"-3" works fine.) That’s what we did and they work just fine for these purposes.

``` **Cleaned-Up Version:** --- *Remember you have to purchase some adapters too. These are for plugging into old robots, lending batteries to other teams, and plugging batteries into existing battery chargers.* *You can also make adapters yourself, which is cheaper than buying them from Andymark, especially if you have extra SB50s. Use short 6-gauge wires between SB50 and SB120 connectors—about 2 to 3 inches usually work. We did this and it worked well.* --- This version maintains the original meaning while adhering to proper formatting and grammar.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
You must purchase some adapters, such as those available at [this link](https://www.andymark.com/products/sb120-to-sb50-adapter), for use with old robots, to lend batteries to other teams, or plug your batteries into existing chargers. While this process can be somewhat tedious, it helps save costs compared to making your own adapters, which are slightly cheaper.

Another consideration is that crimping 4AWG wires can be challenging for some team members, particularly younger or less experienced individuals. Additionally, while this setup can sometimes lead to issues during competitions, such as the SB120 connectors coming loose, simply zipping them together won’t solve the problem. Instead, using flexible 4AWG cables will prevent unnecessary stress and damage to the connections. On the positive side, you no longer need to zip tie the SB120 connectors separately, as was required for the SB50 connectors, which could often lead to them coming loose during competitions.

Why are you considering switching? Are you having issues with brownouts or other battery-related problems?

In my experience, the only time switching from 6AWG to 4AWG will solve your problems is if your current battery leads have bad crimps or bad connections—in which case redoing them will fix the issue. For other problems, switching typically won't help much because the resistance difference is negligible for short runs. At my workplace, we don't consider wire resistance for runs under 10 feet anyway, so making your current battery leads shorter could provide similar benefits if they're excessively long.

If you're facing issues, here's what I recommend: set current limits in the code, use a ramp-up for acceleration, reduce the number or size of active motors, inspect all wiring for good connections, and monitor system performance closely.

Switching doesn't harm anything, so if you fall into those rare cases where it might make a difference, go ahead and do it. Just remember to get some high-flex welding wire if you plan on switching, as it'll be easier to handle.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked: mtuckerFRC4381: With the amp-hungry devices in use today (like Kraken and Vortex), taking steps to reduce the current pathway resistance from battery to the end device can pay off significantly. However, not all efforts are created equal. Upgrading your power cables may seem like a minor improvement, so consider whether it’s worth the trade-off compared to other potential upgrades, such as a vision system or a gyro. If you’re short on funds or time, investing in better battery cables might not be the most efficient use of your resources.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked: I've heard it's typically around a couple tenths of a volt at 250 plus amps saved. It still proved helpful last year, though this year's game didn't push the batteries as hard. It depends somewhat on the robot, but what truly matters is having good crimps and tightened connections, along with keeping the batteries in top shape.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Matt Middleton
posts.cooked: Switched things up for the offseason, impacting various aspects—not just performance or resistance training. Anticipate some surprise costs with a re-equipment program utilizing SB-120’s. These machines will incur a significant amount of expense.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: Not if that same effort or cost can get you greater gains elsewhere. Switching to 4AWG will cost you approximately $17 per SB120, $2 per foot of wire, $2 per copper lug, and probably at least $35 for a good high-leverage crimping tool. Additionally, if you’re doing this, you probably should be using grasshopper connectors at $8 per battery. To do a dozen batteries, 1 charger, and 1 robot could cost you over $500 – specifically: (16 × $17) + (30 × $2) + (24 × $2) + $35 + (12 × $8). [Edit: Forgot the lugs.]

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: We focused on minimizing cable length to achieve significant gains. Reducing lead lengths can yield results comparable to switching to smaller gauges. For additional marginal improvements, we utilize 4AWG/SB120cables. However, arranging the battery, main breaker, and PDP—the CTRE’s Power Distribution Panel—side by side tends to provide even greater benefits.

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked:
Might be a personal preference, but apart from lacking 4ga SB50 wire contacts, there doesn’t seem to be any issues with using an SB50 with 4ga wire in our application. During my field inspections this year, I noticed that when teams use 4ga wire, approximately 80% opt for SB50 and 20% choose SB120. The primary downside is the fact that the largest manufacturer’s SB50 lug is rated for 6ga.

For those concerned about the 50A rating, refer to [the provided PDF](https://www.andersonpower.com/content/dam/app/ecommerce/product-pdfs/SB50/ds-sb50.pdf) for more details. Notably, while the SB50 has a hot plug rating of 50A, the system being tested isn’t experiencing hot plugs, and thus the 50A rating is less critical in this context. Smaller wires are often used in such applications because they better suit the thermal and electrical demands of the devices involved. Our SB50 and 4ga wires operate in open-air conditions, where we haven’t observed significant heating issues.

Regarding the issue of 4ga lugs, there are a few practical solutions. You can expand the existing 6ga lugs by trimming strands (though caution is advised, as pearls may clench), or explore creative solutions like using 4ga-to-6ga adapters. One effective method involves using steel rods with compatible ends and applying appropriate lubrication. While this approach works, it can be slow. If anyone has a more efficient solution, feel free to share!

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: Team 2363 has developed a white paper discussing how to expand the 6 AWG lugs.

link_counts.title: Using 4 AWG cable with the Anderson SB50 connectors – Triple Helix Robotics

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked: I prefer a better option than the $35 crimp tool and am considering getting a hydraulic one instead. The TEMCo TH0006 tool cost around $150 and included half-size dies, which saved me several times when I encountered unusual lug sizes. I appreciate the convenience of that feature. I also hear the Harbor Freight version is popular and often available at around $70, sometimes with deals if you purchase additional items.

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked: Nice, thanks!

posts.name: Cosimo Aho
posts.cooked:
My team (4973) is switching from 6-gauge to 4-gauge (copper) cables, hoping to reduce voltage drop under load. Currently, our robots use Kraken X60s and Falcon 500s, experiencing transients that raise the load to about ~175A. While we haven’t implemented the switch yet, the price difference is minimal—about $10 per wire—and negligible compared to costs like the Power Distribution Hub, roboRIO, etc. New crimps and Anderson connectors will be needed for the 4-gauge cables.

At 26 inches, the electrical resistance comparison shows:

- **6-gauge:** Resistance = 0.8363 mQ, Conductance = 1.1958 kS, Diameter = 4.11 mm  
- **4-gauge:** Resistance = 0.5244 mQ, Conductance = 1.907 kS, Diameter = 5.19 mm  

In summary, the 4-gauge cable is approximately 60% more conductive than the 6-gauge cable for less than double the price, which should reduce voltage drop.
